Rolladen-Schneider.name: Rolladen-Schneider
Rolladen-Schneider.description:
Rolladen-Schneider was a major manufacturer of gliders. Founded by Willi and Walter Schneider and based in Egelsbach near Frankfurt, Germany, the company originally manufactured roller shutters and doors.
Walter, who was a pilot and glider enthusiast, recruited Wolf Lemke, and the company began manufacturing its first gliders in 1967.
The company was declared bankrupt in 2001. In 2003, DG Flugzeugbau bought back the brand and all rights including plans, molds...
The LS8 and LS10 are now produced by DG.

history.text: Made its debut at the German National Championships, taking first and second place.
LS1-c took first place in the Standard Class World Championships at Marfa, Texas.
Helmut Reichmann won the national championship with the LS1-f model.
Became the most flown glider in the German Nationals.
Manufacture of the LS1 was discontinued to focus on the production of the LS3.
Release of the new 15m class LS3, featuring a T-tail-unit with a damped elevator, and flaperons that extend over the whole span.
Introduction of the LS3-a variant. This model omitted the mass balance of the flaps, and increased the water ballast from 120 to 150 kg.
During the German Championships, 13 out of 33 pilots flew an LS3 or LS3-a in the 15m class. Five new women world records were flown.
The LS6 superseded the LS3. A total of 429 LS3 planes were built.
LS4 won the first World Championship after its production start.
Won the European Championship.
At the World Championship, pilots flying the LS4 took the first six places.
Production of the LS4 was stopped due to the takeover of Rolladen-Schneider by DG.
LS4 can be retrofitted with winglets, a change that has to be certified by a licensed workshop or examiner.
Currently 241 LS4, 144 LS4-a and 143 LS4-b are registered in Germany.
LS6 made its maiden flight.
Production commenced for the 15m racer. Giesela Weinreich won the German championship.
First two places were won at the world competitions in Riety.
The 17.5m version of the LS6c appeared without winglets but with interchangeable wing tips.
Further development led to the LS8 model.
Production ended, with 375 units built in 6 different models.
Designed by Wolf Lemke.
Went into production. Competed with ASW 24 by Schleicher.
Winglets were introduced to improve circling performance.
Production was stopped after only 164 aircraft were built.
Entered production for the first time.
1st, 2nd, 3rd at the World Gliding Championships in St Auban, France.
A total of 491 examples of all subtypes had been manufactured by December.
Development began as a successor to the LS6 by Rolladen-Schneider.
The LS10-a prototype made its first flight at Egelsbach.
The prototype won competitions at Hockenheim and Bayreuth.
The prototype won the German Championships at Lüsse.
The LS10 received its certification.
DG Flugzeugbau began production of the LS10.

Schempp-Hirth.name: Schempp-Hirth
Schempp-Hirth.description: Martin Schempp founded the company "Sportflugzeugbau Göppingen Martin Schempp" in 1935, later partnering with Wolf Hirth to rename it "Sportflugzeugbau Schempp-Hirth." Initially known for rivaling popular gliders, the company also contributed to WWII efforts, including aircraft designs. Post-war, the firm briefly manufactured household items due to allied restrictions, returning to glider production in 1951. Leadership changed hands over the years, notably to Klaus Holighaus in 1972, who became the sole owner in 1977. After his death in 1994, the company stayed in the Holighaus family, now managed by Tilo and Brigitte Holighaus, and employs around 100 people. The company has also licensed its designs to other firms.

history.text: The Schempp-Hirth Cirrus made its first flight, designed by Klaus Holighaus.
The Cirrus won the German Championship.
A Cirrus won the World Championship in the open class at Leszno, Poland.
Production of 107 units completed in Germany.
Production continued under license by Vazduhoplovno Tehnicki Centar (VTC) in Vrsac, Yugoslavia, until this year.
The Standard Cirrus made its first flight, developed by Klaus Holighaus.
200 units were produced under license by Grob.
Production by Schempp-Hirth stopped with a total of 700 units built.
Lanaverre Industrie in France built 30 units under license.
Vazduhoplovno Tehnicki Centar VTC in Yugoslavia built 14 units.
Last version G/81 was built by VTC, featuring various modifications.
The Mini-Nimbus was introduced, developed by Schempp-Hirth as a smaller version of the Nimbus-2.
The Nimbus-2 made its first flight.
The Nimbus-2C variant was introduced with flaps.
The Nimbus-3 made its first flight.
The Nimbus-3 was made available in the market.
Introduction of the Nimbus-3D variant.
The Nimbus-4 made its first flight.
The Nimbus-4 was officially made available.
The Nimbus-4DM, a motorized version, was introduced.
The Discus a made its first flight.
The Discus a won the World Championships.
Introduction of the Discus b with winglets.
The Discus a made its first flight.
The Discus a won the World Championships.
Introduction of the Discus b with winglets.
The Discus a made its first flight.
The Discus a won the World Championships.
Introduction of the Discus b with winglets.
The Schempp-Hirth Discus-2 was manufactured for the first time, replacing the Discus.
Launch of the version with an 18-meter wingspan, named Discus-2C 18m.
The Schempp-Hirth Discus-2 was manufactured for the first time, replacing the Discus.
Launch of the version with an 18-meter wingspan, named Discus-2C 18m.
The Schempp-Hirth Discus-2 was manufactured for the first time, replacing the Discus.
Launch of the version with an 18-meter wingspan, named Discus-2C 18m.
The Duo Discus makes its first flight, replacing the Janus as Schempp-Hirth's high-performance two-seater glider.
Introduction of the improved Duo Discus X version; over 400 units were built this year.
Introduction of the original Ventus a
Ventus a wins the World Championships in Paderborn, Germany
Introduction of the Ventus a/16.6 variant with a 16.6m wingspan
Introduction of the Ventus aT, featuring a sustainer engine
First flight of the original Ventus b
Introduction of the Ventus b/16.6 variant with a 16.6m wingspan
Introduction of the Ventus bT, featuring a sustainer engine
First flight of the original Ventus C
Introduction of the Ventus cM version with sustainer motor
Schempp-Hirth Ventus 2 introduit en remplacement du Ventus original
Le Ventus 2A gagne tous les championnats du monde
Fuselage du Schempp-Hirth Discus 2 utilisé pour les versions 2AX, 2BX et 2CX
Schempp-Hirth Ventus 2 introduit en remplacement du Ventus original
Introduction du Ventus 2B avec un fuselage plus large que la version A
Fuselage du Schempp-Hirth Discus 2 utilisé pour les versions 2AX, 2BX et 2CX
Schempp-Hirth Ventus 2 introduit en remplacement du Ventus original
Introduction du Ventus 2C avec une envergure de 18 mètres
Vol d'essai en configuration 15 mètres, finesse de 45 mesurée
Fuselage du Schempp-Hirth Discus 2 utilisé pour les versions 2AX, 2BX et 2CX
Ventus-3 announced at AERO Friedrichshafen with a mock-up displayed
Prototype's first flight at Flugplatz Hahnweide, Kirchheim unter Teck, Germany
Production of the first seven turbo Ventus 3T started
Ventus 3T competed in the 2017 World Gliding Championships and European Gliding Championships, taking top places
First flight of Sport fuselage with the front electric sustainer engine, Ventus 3F, and the first version with the Performance fuselage, Ventus 3M
Ventus 3T took first place at the World Championships at Hosín
Number of Ventus-3 built reached 200
The Schempp-Hirth Arcus had its first flight.
Production of the electric power unit based on Antares 20E equipment stopped.
The prototype of the Janus glider had its first flight, designed by Dipl-Ing Klaus Holighaus.
Production models of the Janus incorporated several improvements.
The Janus B variant was produced, featuring a fixed-incidence tailplane.
The Janus Ce was certified, incorporating modifications to the cockpit and fin.
The Janus was superseded by the unflapped Duo Discus.
The Janus was further succeeded by the flapped Arcus.
100 Januses were built by this time, plus three motorized Janus CMs.
The Quintus had its first flight.
Quintus won 1st place at the World Gliding Championships (Open Class) in Uvalde, Texas.

Sportine Aviacija.name: Sportine Aviacija
Sportine Aviacija.description: Sportine Aviacija, now known as JSC "Sportinė Aviacija ir Ko," was founded in 1969 and is the only company in the Baltic region specializing in gliders and powered gliders. Their first composite glider, BK-7 "Lietuva" set the standard for future designs. The plant has produced over 20 types of gliders, with the LAK-12 being the most popular, boasting an impeccable safety record since 1978. In recent years, the LAK-17 type was developed, along with its electric variant, the LAK-17B-FES, which promises increased reliability and safety. The company has over 50 years of experience, has designed more than 20 different types of gliders, and has distributed over 1,000 units globally.

history.text: The LAK-12 Lietuva was first flown.
Modifications were made to improve the glider's handling.
The LAK-17 was certified.
The LAK-17B had its first flight.
The LAK-17A had its first flight with FES (Front Electric Sustainer).
A 21-meter version of the LAK-17 had its first flight.
The LAK-17 was certified.
The LAK-17B had its first flight.
The LAK-17A had its first flight with FES (Front Electric Sustainer).
A 21-meter version of the LAK-17 had its first flight.
The LAK-19 had its first flight.
The LAK-19 was certified.
The LAK-19 was introduced as a variant based on the LAK-17, but without flaps.
The first LAK-20 was completed.
The MiniLAK was introduced and exposed during the world gliding competiton.

Jonker.name: Jonker
Jonker.description: Jonker Sailplanes Pty Ltd. (JS) is a South African firm that has grown from a small team of six focused on creating competitive sailplanes to an organization with 16 engineers and over 110 employees. Based at Potchefstroom Airfield, the company specializes in designing, manufacturing, and maintaining sailplanes. Their initial product, the JS1, laid the foundation for their success. In collaboration with M&D Flugzeugbau in Germany, Jonker Sailplanes has evolved into a significant player in the sailplane industry.

history.text: The Jonker JS-1 Revelation had its first flight.
Participated in the World Championship, finishing in 2nd and 4th places.
A version with a 21-meter wingspan had its first flight.
Production started.
Studies for the improved JS-1C 18 EVO version began.
The first flight of the JS-3 Rapture took place.
Type certification of the JS-3 Rapture was achieved with EASA.
The prototype participated in the World Gliding Championships.

Glasflugel.name: Glasflugel
Glasflugel.description: Founded in 1963, Glasflügel revolutionized the gliding world with its large-scale production of the H-301 Libelle, marking the first time a fiberglass aircraft was mass-produced. The company also developed other renowned glider types like the BS-1, Standard Libelle, and Kestrel. After Glasflügel's bankruptcy, Hansjörg Streifeneder took over, establishing Glasflügel Aircraft Service GmbH. Initially focused on maintenance and repair work for Glasflügel aircraft, the company has since expanded its services and now specializes in composite technologies for the international aerospace industry. Streifeneder began this journey by constructing Falcon, an advanced standard class glider, solidifying the company's influence in modern glider design and technology.

history.text: Prototype made its first flight; introduced as successor to the H-301 Libelle
Second place in the Standard Class at the World Championships in Leszno, Poland
Introduction of the 201B variant with retractable gear and optional water ballast system
The H-301 Libelle received the first German and first U.S. Type Certificate issued to an all-fiberglass aircraft.
The H-301 was produced by Glasflügel.
The prototype of the Glasflügel 304 flew for the first time.
Glasflügel, the original manufacturer, folded.
HPH conducted the maiden flight of the completely new 18 metre 304 S Shark.
About 50 HPH Shark sailplanes had been produced, with approximately 50% being Self-launchers.
First flight of the Glasflügel 206 Hornet
Production begins, replacing the Standard Libelle
An improved version, the Hornet C, is produced
Total of 102 Hornets built (89 original, 13 Hornet C)
The maiden flight of the Glasflügel 303 Mosquito took place.
The Mosquito was manufactured by Glasflügel.
The Mosquito was superseded by the Glasflügel 304.

SZD.name: SZD
SZD.description: Allstar PZL Glider, established in 2002, is the successor to the Polish glider manufacturer SZD, which dates back to 1946. Despite facing political and economic challenges, the company has continued to innovate in the field of glider construction. It has introduced modern designs like the SZD-54 PERKOZ and even developed an electric propulsion system. The company has produced over 5,000 gliders and remains a key player in the global gliding community.

history.text: The prototype SZD-9 flew for the first time, piloted by Adam Zientek.
The first production unit, known as SZD-9bis Bocian-1A or simply 'Bocian A,' had its first flight. 11 units were built.
The SZD-9 was exported to 27 countries, including Austria, Australia, Belgium, and more.
Polish pilots set many international records flying SZD-9s.
The first flight of the SZD-24 Foka took place at Bielsko, but faced issues with poorly performing airbrakes.
The second prototype made its first flight, featuring improved air-brakes. It took third place in the 'Standard' class at the 1960 World Gliding Championships in Köln, Germany.
The SZD-24 Foka originated from a design competition within SZD, originally known as 'Delfin', and was intended for both competition and aerobatic flying.
Subsequent versions, including the pre-production variant SZD-24A and up to the SZD-32 Foka 5, introduced more refinements.
The SZD-30 Pirat had its first flight.
Production of the SZD-30 Pirat started.
The first SZD-30C, a later production version with modifications, flew.
Following glue failure in wooden joints, the type certificate holder issued a bulletin reducing certain limiting speeds and prohibiting aerobatic flight.
The SZD-36 Cobra was designed and produced in Poland.
The aircraft was designed for the World Gliding Championships at Marfa, Texas. J. Wroblewski took 2nd and F. Kępka took 3rd places in the Standard Class.
The SZD-39 Cobra 17, a 17m span version, took 5th place at Marfa, flown by Edward Makula.
Following a fatal accident due to wing attachment failure, the British Gliding Association issued a Safety Alert for Cobra owners.
The Jantar 2 made its first flight.
The Jantar 2 was placed second, third and seventh at the 1976 World Gliding Championships.
The Jantar 2B, a variant with its wing raised by 125 mm and angle of incidence reduced by 1.5°, had its first flight.
80 SZD-42s remained on the civil registers of European countries west of Russia.
The design and production of SZD-48 Jantar Standard 2 started in Poland.
First flight of the SZD-48-2 Jantar Standard 2 took place, piloted by January Roman.
The initial design and prototype of the Puchacz series, SZD-50-1 Dromader, first flew.
The initial production variant, SZD-50-2 Puchacz, had its first flight.
The prototype SZD-51-0 was first flown.
The production version, SZD-51-1, was introduced with a modified fuselage. A total of 261 aircraft were built.
The type was proposed for licence production in Brazil, but only a single SZD-51-1 was built there.
The Perkoz had its first flight.
The production of the SZD-50 Puchacz, the predecessor of the Perkoz, was terminated.
The PZL Bielsko SZD-55 Promyk started its production.
The SZD-55 is still in production, with approximately 20 units produced in the United States.
Won over 15 gold and silver medals in international competitions.
Construction of Diana-2 FES (Front Electric Sustainer) prototype was progressing quickly with first test flight planned for December 2017.

Alexander Schleicher.name: Alexander Schleicher
Alexander Schleicher.description:
Alexander Schleicher GmbH is not only one of the world's leading glider manufacturers but also the oldest, founded in 1926 by Alexander Schleicher under the name Alexander Schleicher Segelflugzeugbau. Located in the Wasserkuppe mountain range, the cradle of German gliding, the company played a crucial role in sustaining aeronautical activity in Germany, which was restricted by the Treaty of Versailles. 
From 1933, its gliders were used to promote German aviation propaganda through gliding clubs managed by the Hitler Youth. Collaborating closely with Rhön-Rossitten Gesellschaft, the gliders were often designed by prominent figures like Alexander Lippisch, Fritz Stamer, and Hans Jacobs. Despite the cessation of sport aircraft construction in Germany from 1936 due to material constraints, the company continued its activities until 1945, focusing exclusively on the production and maintenance of gliders.
Through the years, the company has adapted and evolved, maintaining its status as a major player in the global gliding community. Its long-standing history and commitment to quality and innovation have made it a cornerstone in the world of gliding.

history.text: The ASG 29 was introduced by Michael Greiner as his first project.
The engine can be equipped with an electric starter, and this version is called the ASG 29 Es.
The announcement for the study of the ASG-32 was made.
Construction of the prototype began.
The prototype had its first flight in Poppenhausen, Germany, piloted by designer Michael Greiner and Alexander Schleicher's CEO, Peter Kremer.
The first deliveries were announced.
The series production of ASH 25 was officially announced at the 'Aero '85' trade fair in Friedrichshafen.
Taller winglets were added to the ASH 25, increasing its wingspan to 26 m.
The ASH 26 had its first flight.
Over 90% of the ASH 26s sold were the self-launching version, the ASH 26 E, featuring a liquid cooled Diamond (now Austro Engine) AE50R Wankel rotary engine.
The ASH 31 was announced by Alexander Schleicher as a replacement for the ASH 26.
The ASH 31 had its first flight.
100 ASH 31 gliders had been built as of this year.
The prototype of the Schleicher AS 33 had its maiden flight from Huhnrain Airport, Poppenhausen near Frankfurt.
Gerhard Waibel joined Alexander Schleicher GmbH & Co and began his first project, the ASW 12.
Ben Greene and Wally Scott co-set a World Free Distance Record, flying separate ASW-12 sailplanes a distance of 1,153.82 km from Odessa, TX to Columbus, NE.
Hans-Werner Grosse flew an ASW 12 for 1,461 km from Lübeck to Biarritz, setting the World Free Distance Record that stood for thirty years.
The ASW 15 had its first flight.
First flight of the prototype D-0100 at Wasserkuppe, Rhön, Germany, with test pilot Edgar Kremer.
Production run of the ASW-17.
The unique ASW-17X with a 19-meter wingspan was built.
The prototype of the ASW 19 had its first flight.
Production of the ASW 19 began.
An ASW 19 won the Standard Class World Championship in Châteauroux, piloted by Dutch pilot Baer Saelen.
The prototype of the ASW 20 first flew.
The B model was introduced, featuring a reinforced wing spar and other enhancements.
Production of the ASW 20 ended, superseded by the ASW 27.
ASW 20B set a world triangle distance record of 1,435 km.
The ASW 22 first flew.
An ASW 22 broke the world 750 km triangle speed record.
The span was increased to 25 meters for the ASW 22B with a modified inner wing section.
The prototype of the ASW 24 had its first flight, and production began the same year.
Production of the ASW 24 ended, and it was succeeded by the ASW 28.
The ASW 24 won its first World Championship, 14 years after its commercialization.
The ASW 24B variant was introduced, featuring winglets and minor aerodynamic tweaks for improved handling and performance.
The ASW 27 had its first flight.
The ASW 27 was certified.
A total of 236 ASW 27 gliders had been built by this year.
The ASW 28 production began, replacing the ASW 24 in the manufacturing lineup.
Alexander Schleicher introduced an improved version B of the ASW 28 in the 15-meter class, featuring cockpit enhancements and improved aerobrakes.

Let Kunovice.name: Let Kunovice
Let Kunovice.description: Let Kunovice, also known as LET, is a Czech civil aircraft manufacturer originally established in 1936 in Kunovice, Czech Republic. The company is particularly renowned for its LET L-13 Blaník gliders and Let L-410 Turbolet twin-engine aircraft, which has been produced in over 1,000 units since the 1970s. The company went through multiple ownership changes: it was acquired by the American firm Ayres Corporation in 1998, which went bankrupt in 2001. In 2005, Czech private group PAMCO took over, and the business continued as Aircraft Industries. In June 2008, Russia's Ural Mining and Metallurgical Company (UGMK) acquired a 51% stake in the company.

DG.name: DG Flugzeugbau
DG.description: Founded in 1973 by Gerhard Glaser and Wilhelm Dirks, Glaser-Dirks Flugzeugbau GmbH specialized in producing safe and efficient gliders, starting with the revolutionary DG-100 model. Over the years, the company has expanded its range to include various versions like the DG-200, DG-300, and DG-400, among others. Despite facing financial hardships and a brief halt in production in the mid-'90s, the company continued its operations and has delivered over 1,700 units as of August 1998. They are known for incorporating the latest technologies and prioritizing safety and performance in their designs.

Binder.name: Binder
Binder.description: Founded in 1979 by Walter Binder, Binder Flugmotoren- und Flugzeugbau specializes in self-launching gliders. Located near the Wasserkuppe, known as the "cradle of German gliding", the company has won two world championships with its EB-family of gliders. Walter's nephew, Oliver Binder, a competitive glider pilot, took over the company in 2012. The company employs 10 staff and is known for its technical expertise and customer service. Test flights are conducted at the nearby Ostheimer Flugplatz Büchig.

Grob.name: Grob
Grob.description: Grob Aircraft, founded in 1971 in Germany, specializes in gliders and general aviation aircraft. Known for using carbon fiber reinforced polymer, the company has delivered over 4,500 airframes globally. Initially a subcontractor for Schempp-Hirth, Grob transitioned to independent production, focusing on cost-effective, full-composite gliders for the club market.

history.text: First flight of the Grob G 102 Astir
Introduction of the Astir CS model
Introduction of the Astir CS Jeans version for club market
Performance improvements with the Astir CS 77 version
Launch of the Astir III version
Introduction of improved wing model for Astir CS 77
Production of the Astir ceased

Centrair.name: Centrair
Centrair.description: Centrair, a French company founded in 1970 by Marc and Genevieve Ranjon, originally acted as an agent for Alexander Schleicher GmbH & Co. It started manufacturing gliders under license, including the ASW 20 and Scheibe SF 34. In 1981, Centrair introduced its own sailplane, the C101 Pegase, using the ASW 20 fuselage. Although not competitive in the Standard Class, the Pegase became a popular club aircraft. Centrair also briefly ventured into powered business aircraft design and produced the C201 Marianne two-seater glider in the 1980s. The company dissolved after building 80 Mariannes.

Bölkow.name: Bölkow
Bölkow.description: Bölkow was a German aerospace company founded in 1948, mainly known for its work in helicopters and powered aircraft. However, they also produced gliders like the Bölkow Phoebus, which was notable for its early use of composite materials. In 1969, Bölkow merged with other companies to form Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm (MBB), which later became part of Airbus Group. While gliders were not their main focus, Bölkow's innovations in composite materials left a mark on glider design.

Eiri-Avion.name: Eiri-Avion
Eiri-Avion.description: Eiri-Avion is an Estonian glider manufacturer known for producing the PIK-20, a high-performance, single-seat fiberglass glider. Originally designed by the Polytechnic Institute of Finland, Eiri-Avion acquired the manufacturing rights and has produced various versions of the PIK-20. The glider is well-regarded for its performance and has been used in various gliding competitions.
